message.content:
Verb tenses refer to the different forms a verb can take depending on when an action takes place in relation to the moment of speaking. There are several types of verb tenses, including:

1. Present Tense - used for actions happening now or general truths
2. Past Tense - used for actions that have already happened
3. Future Tense - used for actions that will happen in the future
4. Progressive Aspect - indicates an action is ongoing or in progress
5. Perfect Aspect - indicates an action has been completed or is ongoing up to the present moment
6. Continuous/Progressive Perfect Aspect - combines the perfect aspect with the progressive aspect, indicating an action that started in the past and continues up to the present moment
7. Perfect Continuous/Progressive - combines the perfect aspect with the progressive aspect, indicating an ongoing action that was completed at some point in the past
8. Simple Tenses (Present, Past, Future) can also be combined with modal verbs like "can," "could," "may," "might," "must," "shall," "should," and "will" to express different levels of certainty or obligation.

These are some of the most common verb tenses used in English. There may be variations depending on the specific language being discussed.
